revision.text:
[[Image:Drawing of the Missile Guidance Computer used on Titan II, the ASC-15 made by IBM in Owego, NY.jpg|right|thumb|300px|ASC-15 digital computer.]]
The '''ASC-15''' (Advance System Controller Model 15) was a [[digital computer]] developed by [[International Business Machines]] (IBM) for use on the [[Titan (rocket family)|Titan II]] intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM).<ref>1958: "IBM develops the ASC-15 guidance computer for the United States Air Force Titan II missile computer. " [http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/exhibits/space/space_chronology.html IBM Archives: Space flight chronology]. See also Bilstein, Stages to Saturn, p. 243. See also Olsen and Orrange, p. 406</ref><ref>http://ed-thelen.org/comp-hist/BRL61-a.html</ref> It was subsequently modified and used on the [[Titan III]] and [[Saturn I]] Block II launch vehicles.
Its principal function on these rockets was to make navigation calculations using data from [[Inertial measurement unit|inertial sensor systems]]. It also performed readiness checks before launch.<ref>Larson, p. 7</ref> It was a digital serial processor using fixed-point data with 27-bit words. The storage was a [[drum memory]]. Electronic circuits were welded encapsulated modules, consisting of discrete [[resistor]]s, [[transistor]]s, [[capacitor]]s, and other components welded together and encapsulated in a foam material. It was manufactured in the IBM plant at [[Owego (town), New York|Owego]], NY.<ref>Larson, p. 4. See also: Martin H. Weik. "A Third Survey of Domestic Electronic Digital Computing Systems" Ballistic Research Laboratories, Aberdeen Proving Ground, Maryland Report No. 1115, March 1961 http://ed-thelen.org/comp-hist/BRL61-a.html pages 58-59.</ref>
== ASC-15 for Titan II ==
The first inertial guidance system for the [[LGM-25C Titan II|Titan II]] was built by [[AC Spark Plug]], and included an inertial measurement unit based in designs from [[Draper Labs]] at [[MIT]] and the ASC-15 computer designed and built by IBM in Owego, NY. The first Titan II missile carrying this system was launched 16 March 1962. Acquiring spares for this system became difficult, and the Air Force decided to replace it with a new system. The AC Spark Plug system, including the ASC-15, was replaced by the [[Delco Electronics]] [[Universal Space Guidance System]] (USGS) on operational Titan II missiles starting in January 1978.<ref>David K. Stumpf. Titan II. A History of a Cold War Missile Program. University of Arkansas Press, Fayetteville, Arkansas, 2000. {{ISBN|1-55728-601-9}}. Pages 63-67.</ref> The guidance computer in the USGS was the [[Magic 352]], made by Delco.<ref>A.C. Liang and D.L. Kleinbub."Navigation of the Titan IIIC space launch vehicle using the Carousel VB IMU." AIAA Guidance and Control Conference, Key Biscayne, FL, 20–22 August 1973. AIAA Paper No. 73-905.</ref>
The ASC-15 was built on an aluminum frame about 1.5x1.5x1 feet.<ref>Estimate based on mensuration of photographs of the ASC-15 and a volume of {{convert|2.12|cuft|m3}} reported in "Spaceborne Digital Computer Systems," NASA, SP-8070, March 1971.</ref> The sides, top and bottom were covered by pieces of laminated plastic, covered with gold-plated aluminum foil. These covers were slightly convex and ribbed for stiffness. Inside the covers were fifty-two logic sticks, each containing four welded encapsulated modules. These surrounded a bell frame housing a drum memory.<ref>"Missile Launch/Missile Officer (LGM-25) Missile Systems." USAF, Sheppard Technical Training Center, May 1967. Student Study Guide OBR1821F/3121f-V-1 thru 4, Volume I of II.</ref> See Figure 2.
The drum was a thin-walled stainless steel cylinder 3 inches long and 4.5 inches in diameter covered with a magnetic nickel-cobalt alloy. It was driven by a synchronous motor at 6,000 rpm. The drum had 70 tracks, of which 58 were used and 12 were spare. These tracks were used as follows: {| border="1" ! width="80"|NO. TRACKS ! width="230"|USE OF TRACKS |- | align="center" | 34 || Instruction tracks |- | align="center" | 7 || Constants |- | align="center" | 8 || Target data |- | align="center" | 2 || Data for temporary storage |- | align="center" | 5 || Revolvers for extra fast access storage |- | align="center" | 2 || Timing tracks |}
The capacity of a track was 1,728 bits. Instruction words were 9-bits long, and data was stored in 27-bit words.<ref>A.E. Cooper and W.T. Chow. "Development of On-board Space Computer Systems" IBM Journal of Research and Development, January 1976. Pages 5-18.</ref>
Coincident with 58 tracks were 67 read heads and 13 write heads. While the drum was spinning at 6,000 rpm, the heads floated above the surface of the drum on a thin layer of air. When the drum was spinning up or slowing down, the heads were raised off the drum by camshafts rotated by a chain that was driven by a motor on top of the drum housing, to avoid scoring the magnetic surface. See Figure 3.
== ASC-15 for Titan III ==
The [[Titan III]] was a space launch vehicle based on the Titan II ICBM. The ASC-15 was kept as the vehicle guidance computer, but the drum was lengthened slightly to provide 78 usable tracks, an increase of 20 over the drum used in the Titan II. The memory held 9,792 instructions (51 tracks) and 1,152 constants (18 tracks). The speed was the same as for the Titan II: 100 revolutions/second × 64 words/revolution × 27 bits/word = 172.8 kilobits/second. The time for an addition operation was 156 [[Microsecond|µs]]; for a multiplication, 1,875 [[Microsecond|µs]]; and for a division, 7,968 [[Microsecond|µs]].<ref>Paul O. Larson. "Titan III Inertial Guidance System". AIAA Paper No. 65-306. AIAA Second Annual Meeting, 26–29 July 1965, San Francisco, CA.</ref>
== ASC-15 for Saturn I ==
No guidance computer was used for Saturn I Block I (missions SA-1, 2, 3 and 4). The guidance system for SA-2 is shown in Figure 4.<ref>F.W. Brandner. "Technical Information Summary Concerning Saturn Vehicle SA-2.". NASA MSFC Memo dated 5 April 1962. TMX 51831. 16 pages https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19650076118_1965076118.pdf</ref> The pitch program was provided by a cam device located in the Servo Loop Amplifier Box. The sequence of events was controlled by a program device that was also used on Jupiter missiles. This was a 6-track tape recorder that sent pulses to a set of relays (the flight sequencer) to activate and deactivate various circuits in a precisely timed sequence.
The ASC-15 was first flown on SA-5, the first Saturn I Block II vehicle and the first to achieve orbit.<ref>Saturn Flight Evaluation Working Group. "Results of the Fifth Saturn I Launch Vehicle Test Flight (SA-5)." NASA MSFC 22 September 1964. MPR-SAT-FE-64-17. https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19650060677_1965060677.pdf.</ref> It was a passenger on this mission, not guiding the vehicle but generating test data for later evaluation. The active guidance system on SA-5 was similar to that of earlier flights. The passenger system was the ASC-15 and the [[ST-124-M3 inertial platform|ST-124 inertial platform]]. Guidance was open loop; that is guidance commands were functions only of time. SA-5 also saw the introduction of the [[Saturn V Instrument Unit|Instrument Unit]].
On SA-6, while open loop ST-90S guidance was used for the first stage (S-I), after separation the ST-124 and ASC-15 used path adaptive guidance (closed loop) to control the second stage (S-IV). The SA-6 guidance system is shown in Figure 5.<ref>Saturn Flight Evaluation Working Group. "Results of the Sixth Saturn I Launch Vehicle Test Flight (SA-6)." NASA MSFC 1 October 1964. MPR-SAT-FE-64-18. https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19700089115_1970089115.pdf</ref> The effectiveness of the path adaptive guidance was demonstrated inadvertently when premature shutdown of S-IV engine number eight had virtually no effect on the vehicle trajectory.
The arrangement of the ST-90S and ST-124 systems (including the ASC-15 guidance computer) on SA-6 is shown in Figure 6.<ref>"Apollo Systems Reliability Status Report. Volume II: Subsystems Reliability Status DRAFT." NASA, Washington, DC, 23 September 1963. 225 pages. https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19750069412_1975069412.pdf</ref> This is version 1 of the Instrument Unit, which flew on SA-5, 6, and 7.
On SA-7 the ST-124 system guided the firing of both stages. The guidance and control system for SA-7 is shown in Figure 7.<ref>Saturn Flight Evaluation Working Group. "Results of the Seventh Saturn I Launch Vehicle Test Flight (SA-7)." NASA MSFC 30 December 1964. MPR-SAT-FE-64-19. https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19740074283_1974074283.pdf</ref> The digital computer is the ASC-15. It replaced both the cam device that contained the S-I tilt program for earlier missions.<ref>"Saturn I Summary." NASA MSFC, 15 Feb 1966. 43 pages. {{hdl|2060/19660014308}} . "Results of the Seventh Saturn I Launch Vehicle Test Flight (SA-7)." PDF page 113.</ref> and the program device that controlled the sequence of events on those missions.
The next mission flown after SA-7 was SA-9. It carried a new version of the Instrument Unit, one that was unpressurized and {{convert|2|ft|m}} shorter than version 1. Version 2 flew on the remaining Saturn I missions (SA-8, 9, and 10), and is shown under construction at MSFC in Figure 8.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mix.msfc.nasa.gov/IMAGES/HIGH/6412716.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709121113/http://mix.msfc.nasa.gov/IMAGES/HIGH/6412716.jpg |archivedate=2011-07-09 |df= }}. "This image depicts a high angle view of technicians working on the instrument unit (IU) component assembly for the SA-8 mission in Marshall Space Flight Center's building 4705."</ref> Figure 9 is a blowup of this image, showing the dummy ASC-15 and dummy ST-124.
== Gallery ==
<gallery>
Image:Drawing of the Missile Guidance Computer used on Titan II, the ASC-15 made by IBM in Owego, NY.jpg|Missile Guidance Computer (MGC) for Titan II. Image:Fig68-explodedMGC.jpg|Exploded view of MGC. Image:TitanII MGC magnetic drum.jpg|Drum memory of the ASC-15 Image:SA-2 control systemMOD.jpg|SA-2 control system Image: SA-6 guidance and control systemMOD.jpg|SA-6 guidance and control system Image:SA-6 InstrumentUnit 19790076698.jpg|Instrument Unit for SA-6 Image:SA-7 guidance and control systemMOD.jpg|SA-7 guidance and control system Image:Saturn V Instrument Unit (MSFC-6412716).jpg|SA-8 instrument unit under construction at Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) Image:6412716-crop01.jpg|Detail of SA-8 instrument unit, with dummies marked for ASC-15 and ST-124. </gallery>

{{Infobox mineral | name = Ahlfeldite | category = Selenite mineral | image = | caption = | formula = (Ni,Co)SeO3·2H2O | molweight = | strunz = 4.JH.10 | system = [[Monoclinic]] | class = Prismatic (2/m)
(same [[H-M symbol]]) | symmetry = ''P''21/m | color = | habit = | twinning = | cleavage = | fracture = | mohs = | luster = | refractive = | opticalprop = | birefringence = | pleochroism = | streak = | gravity = | density = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = | other = | references = [http://webmineral.com/data/Ahlfeldite.shtml Webmineral.com - Ahlfeldite][http://www.mindat.org/min-61.html Mindat.org - Ahlfeldite][http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/ahlfeldite.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy - Ahlfeldite] }} '''Ahlfeldite''' (([[nickel|Ni]],[[cobalt|Co]])[[[selenium|Se]][[oxygen|O]]3]·2[[hydrogen|H]]2O) is a [[mineral]] of secondary origin. It's named after [[Friedrich Ahlfeld]] (1892–1982), a German-Bolivian mining engineer and geologist. Its [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]] is Virgen de Surumi mine, Pakajake Canyon, [[Chayanta Province]], [[Potosí Department]], [[Bolivia]]. == References == {{mineral-stub}} [[Category:Nickel minerals]] [[Category:Cobalt minerals]] [[Category:Monoclinic minerals]]

revision.text:
[[File:Shear Moment Diagram.svg|thumb|400px|[[Shear and moment diagram]] for a simply supported beam with a concentrated load at mid-span.]] A '''bending moment''' is the reaction induced in a [[structural element]] when an external [[force]] or [[Moment of force|moment]] is applied to the element causing the element to [[bending|bend]].<ref name=timo/><ref name=beer/> The most common or simplest structural element subjected to bending moments is the [[Beam (structure)|beam]]. The diagram shows a beam which is simply supported at both ends. Simply supported means that each end of the beam can rotate; therefore each end support has no bending moment. The ends can only react to the shear loads. Other beams can have both ends fixed; therefore each end support has both bending moment and shear reaction loads. Beams can also have one end fixed and one end simply supported. The simplest type of beam is the cantilever, which is fixed at one end and is free at the other end (neither simple or fixed). In reality, beam supports are usually neither absolutely fixed nor absolutely rotating freely.
The internal reaction loads in a [[cross section (geometry)|cross-section]] of the structural element can be resolved into a [[resultant force]] and a resultant [[couple (mechanics)|couple]]. For equilibrium, the moment created by external forces (and external moments) must be balanced by the couple induced by the internal loads. The resultant internal couple is called the '''bending moment''' while the resultant internal force is called the '''shear force''' (if it is transverse to the plane of element) or the '''normal force''' (if it is along the plane of the element).
The bending moment at a [[cross section (geometry)|section]] through a structural element may be defined as "the sum of the moments about that section of all external forces acting to one side of that section". The forces and moments on either side of the section must be equal in order to counteract each other and maintain a state of [[Dynamic equilibrium|equilibrium]] so the same bending moment will result from summing the moments, regardless of which side of the section is selected. If clockwise bending moments are taken as negative, then a negative bending moment within an element will cause "sagging", and a positive moment will cause "hogging". It is therefore clear that a point of zero bending moment within a [[Beam (structure)|beam]] is a point of [[contraflexure]]—that is the point of transition from hogging to sagging or vice versa.
Moments and [[torque]]s are measured as a force multiplied by a distance so they have as unit [[newton-metre]]s (N·m), or [[pound-foot (torque)|pound-foot]] (lbf·ft). The concept of bending moment is very important in [[engineering]] (particularly in [[Civil engineering|civil]] and [[mechanical engineering]]) and [[physics]].
== Background == [[Tensile]] and [[compressive]] stresses increase proportionally with bending moment, but are also dependent on the [[second moment of area]] of the cross-section of a beam (that is, the shape of the cross-section, such as a circle, square or I-beam being common structural shapes). Failure in bending will occur when the bending moment is sufficient to induce tensile stresses greater than the [[Yield (engineering)|yield]] stress of the material throughout the entire cross-section. In structural analysis, this bending failure is called a plastic hinge, since the full load carrying ability of the structural element is not reached until the full cross-section is past the yield stress. It is possible that failure of a structural element in [[Shearing (physics)|shear]] may occur before failure in bending, however the mechanics of failure in shear and in bending are different.
Moments are calculated by multiplying the external [[vector (geometric)|vector]] [[force]]s (loads or reactions) by the vector distance at which they are applied. When analysing an entire element, it is sensible to calculate moments at both ends of the element, at the beginning, centre and end of any uniformly distributed loads, and directly underneath any point loads. Of course any "pin-joints" within a structure allow free rotation, and so zero moment occurs at these points as there is no way of transmitting turning forces from one side to the other.
It is more common to use the convention that a clockwise bending moment to the left of the point under consideration is taken as positive. This then corresponds to the second derivative of a function which, when positive, indicates a curvature that is 'lower at the centre' i.e. sagging. When defining moments and curvatures in this way calculus can be more readily used to find slopes and deflections.
Critical values within the beam are most commonly annotated using a [[Shear and moment diagram|bending moment diagram]], where negative moments are plotted to scale above a horizontal line and positive below. Bending moment varies linearly over unloaded sections, and parabolically over uniformly loaded sections.
Engineering descriptions of the computation of bending moments can be confusing because of unexplained sign conventions and implicit assumptions. The descriptions below use vector mechanics to compute moments of force and bending moments in an attempt to explain, from first principles, why particular sign conventions are chosen.
== Computing the moment of force == [[File:beam moment plain.svg|thumb|300px|Computing the moment of force in a beam.]] An important part of determining bending moments in practical problems is the computation of moments of force. Let <math>\mathbf{F}</math> be a force vector acting at a point '''A''' in a body. The moment of this force about a reference point ('''O''') is defined as<ref name=beer>{{Citation|last=Beer|first=F.|last2=Johnston|first2=E.R.|title=Vector mechanics for engineers: statics|publisher=McGraw Hill|year=1984|pages=62–76}}</ref> :<math> \mathbf{M} = \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{F} </math> where <math>\mathbf{M}</math> is the moment vector and <math>\mathbf{r}</math> is the position vector from the reference point ('''O''') to the point of application of the force ('''A'''). The <math>\times</math> symbol indicates the vector cross product. For many problems, it is more convenient to compute the moment of force about an axis that passes through the reference point '''O'''. If the unit vector along the axis is <math>\mathbf{e}</math>, the moment of force about the axis is defined as :<math> M = \mathbf{e}\cdot\mathbf{M} = \mathbf{e}\cdot(\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{F}) </math> where <math>\cdot</math> indicates the vector dot product.
=== Example === The adjacent figure shows a beam that is acted upon by a force <math>F</math>. If the coordinate system is defined by the three unit vectors <math>\mathbf{e}_x, \mathbf{e}_y, \mathbf{e}_z</math>, we have the following :<math> \mathbf{F} = 0\,\mathbf{e}_x - F\,\mathbf{e}_y + 0\,\mathbf{e}_z \quad \text{and} \quad \mathbf{r} = x\,\mathbf{e}_x + 0\,\mathbf{e}_y + 0\,\mathbf{e}_z \,. </math> Therefore, :<math> \mathbf{M} = \mathbf{r}\times\mathbf{F} = \left|\begin{matrix}\mathbf{e}_x & \mathbf{e}_y & \mathbf{e}_z \\ x & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -F & 0 \end{matrix}\right| = -Fx\,\mathbf{e}_z \,. </math> The moment about the axis <math>\mathbf{e}_z</math> is then :<math> M_z = \mathbf{e}_z\cdot\mathbf{M} = -Fx \,. </math>
=== Sign conventions === The negative value suggests that a moment that tends to rotate a body clockwise around an axis should have a '''negative''' sign. However, the actual sign depends on the choice of the three axes <math>\mathbf{e}_x, \mathbf{e}_y, \mathbf{e}_z</math>. For instance, if we choose another right handed coordinate system with <math>\mathbf{E}_x = \mathbf{e}_x, \mathbf{E}_y = -\mathbf{e}_z, \mathbf{E}_z = \mathbf{e}_y</math>, we have :<math> \mathbf{F} = 0\,\mathbf{E}_x + 0\,\mathbf{E}_y -F\,\mathbf{E}_z \quad \text{and} \quad \mathbf{r} = x\,\mathbf{E}_x + 0\,\mathbf{E}_y + 0\,\mathbf{E}_z \,. </math> Then, :<math> \mathbf{M} = \mathbf{r}\times\mathbf{F} = \left|\begin{matrix}\mathbf{E}_x & \mathbf{E}_y & \mathbf{E}_z \\ x & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -F \end{matrix}\right| = Fx\,\mathbf{E}_y \quad \text{and} \quad M_y = \mathbf{E}_y\cdot\mathbf{M} = Fx \,. </math> For this new choice of axes, a '''positive''' moment tends to rotate body clockwise around an axis.
== Computing the bending moment == In a rigid body or in an unconstrained deformable body, the application of a moment of force causes a pure rotation. But if a deformable body is constrained, it develops internal forces in response to the external force so that equilibrium is maintained. An example is shown in the figure below. These internal forces will cause local deformations in the body.
For equilibrium, the sum of the internal force vectors is equal to the applied external force and the sum of the moment vectors created by the internal forces is equal to the moment of the external force. The internal force and moment vectors are oriented in such a way that the total force (internal + external) and moment (external + internal) of the system is zero. The internal moment vector is called the '''bending moment'''.<ref name=timo>{{Citation|last=Gere|first=J.M.|last2=Timoshenko|first2=S.P.|title=Mechanics of Materials:Forth edition|year=1996|publisher=Nelson Engineering|isbn=0534934293}}</ref>
Though bending moments have been used to determine the stress states in arbitrary shaped structures, the physical interpretation of the computed stresses is problematic. However, physical interpretations of bending moments in beams and plates have a straightforward interpretation as the [[stress resultants]] in a cross-section of the structural element. For example, in a beam in the figure, the bending moment vector due to stresses in the cross-section ''A'' perpendicular to the ''x''-axis is given by :<math> \mathbf{M}_x = \int_A \mathbf{r} \times (\sigma_{xx} \mathbf{e}_x + \sigma_{xy} \mathbf{e}_y + \sigma_{xz} \mathbf{e}_z)\, dA \quad \text{where} \quad \mathbf{r} = y\,\mathbf{e}_y + z\,\mathbf{e}_z \,. </math> Expanding this expression we have, :<math> \mathbf{M}_x = \int_A \left(-y\sigma_{xx}\mathbf{e}_z + y\sigma_{xz}\mathbf{e}_x + z\sigma_{xx}\mathbf{e}_y - z\sigma_{xy}\mathbf{e}_x\right)dA =: M_{xx}\,\mathbf{e}_x + M_{xy}\,\mathbf{e}_y + M_{xz}\,\mathbf{e}_z\,. </math> We define the bending moment components as :<math> \begin{bmatrix} M_{xx} \\ M_{xy} \\M_{xz} \end{bmatrix} := \int_A \begin{bmatrix} y\sigma_{xz} - z\sigma_{xy} \\ z\sigma_{xx} \\ -y\sigma_{xx} \end{bmatrix}\,dA \,. </math> The internal moments are computed about an origin that is at the neutral axis of the beam or plate and the integration is through the thickness (<math>h</math>)
=== Example === [[File:beam bending moment plain.svg|thumb|300px|Computing the bending moment in a beam.]] In the beam shown in the adjacent figure, the external forces are the applied force at point '''A''' (<math>-F\mathbf{e}_y</math>) and the reactions at the two support points '''O''' and '''B''' (<math>\mathbf{R}_O = R_O\mathbf{e}_y</math> and <math> \mathbf{R}_B = R_B\mathbf{e}_y</math>). The reactions can be computed using balances of forces and moments about point '''A''', i.e., :<math> R_O + R_B - F = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad -\mathbf{r}_A\times\mathbf{R}_O + \mathbf{r}_B\times\mathbf{R}_B = \mathbf{0} \,. </math> If <math>L</math> is the length of the beam, we have :<math> \mathbf{r}_A = x_A\mathbf{e}_x \quad \text{and} \quad \mathbf{r}_B = (L-x_A)\mathbf{e}_x \,. </math> If we solve for the reactions we have :<math> R_O = \left(1 - \frac{x_A}{L}\right) F \quad \text{and} \quad R_B = \frac{x_A}{L}\,F \,. </math> Looking at the free body diagram of the part of the beam to the left of point '''X''', the total moment of the external forces about the point '''X''' is :<math> \mathbf{M} = -(\mathbf{r}_X-\mathbf{r}_A)\times\mathbf{F} - \mathbf{r}_X\times\mathbf{R}_O = \left[(x_A-x)\mathbf{e}_x\right]\times\left(-F\mathbf{e}_y\right) - \left(x\mathbf{e}_x\right)\times\left(R_O\mathbf{e}_y\right) \,. </math> If we compute the cross products, we have :<math> \mathbf{M} = \left|\begin{matrix}\mathbf{e}_x & \mathbf{e}_y & \mathbf{e}_z \\ x_A - x & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -F & 0 \end{matrix}\right| - \left|\begin{matrix}\mathbf{e}_x & \mathbf{e}_y & \mathbf{e}_z \\ x & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & R_0 & 0 \end{matrix}\right| = F(x-x_A)\,\mathbf{e}_z -R_0x\,\mathbf{e}_z = -\frac{F x_A}{L}(L-x)\,\mathbf{e}_z \,. </math> For this situation, the only non-zero component of the bending moment is :<math> \mathbf{M}_{xz} = -\left[\int_z\int_{-h/2}^{h/2} y\,\sigma_{xx}\,dy\,dz\right]\mathbf{e}_z \,. </math> For the sum of the moments at '''X''' about the axis <math>\mathbf{e}_z</math> to be zero, we require :<math> \mathbf{M} + \mathbf{M}_{xz} = \mathbf{0} \quad \text{or} \quad -\frac{F x_A}{L}(L-x) + M_{xz} = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad M_{xz} =\frac{F x_A}{L}(L-x) \,. </math> At <math>x = x_A</math>, we have <math>M_{xz} = Fx_A(L-x_A)/L</math>.
=== Sign convention === In the above discussion, it is implicitly assumed that the bending moment is positive when the top of the beam is compressed. That can be seen if we consider a linear distribution of stress in the beam and find the resulting bending moment. Let the top of the beam be in compression with a stress <math>-\sigma_0</math> and let the bottom of the beam have a stress <math>\sigma_0</math>. Then the stress distribution in the beam is <math>\sigma_{xx}(y) = -y\sigma_0</math>. The bending moment due to these stresses is :<math> M_{xz} = -\left[\int_z\int_{-h/2}^{h/2} y\,(-y\sigma_0)\,dy\,dz\right] = \sigma_0\,I </math> where <math>I</math> is the [[area moment of inertia]] of the cross-section of the beam. Therefore the bending moment is positive when the top of the beam is in compression.
Many authors follow a different convention in which the stress resultant <math>M_{xz}</math> is defined as :<math> \mathbf{M}_{xz} = \left[\int_z\int_{-h/2}^{h/2} y\,\sigma_{xx}\,dy\,dz\right]\mathbf{e}_z \,. </math> In that case, positive bending moments imply that the top of the beam is in tension. Of course, the definition of '''top''' depends on the coordinate system being used. In the examples above, the top is the location with the largest <math>y</math>-coordinate.

{{Infobox Website | name = BugGuide | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://bugguide.net/}} | slogan = | commercial = No | type = [[Entomology]], [[Citizen science]] | language = English | registration = not required | owner = [[Iowa State University]] | author = | launch date = {{Start date and age|2003|df=yes|br=yes}} | current status = Online }} '''BugGuide''' (or '''BugGuide.net''') is a [[website]] and [[online community]] of [[Natural history|naturalists]], both amateur and professional, who share observations of [[insect]]s, [[spider]]s, and other related creatures.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/article/20110731/LIFE/307310010/-1/GETPUBLISHED03/Discovering-bugs-her-passion|title=Discovering bugs and her passion|work=[[The Des Moines Register]]|date=July 31, 2011|accessdate=15 August 2011}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The website consists of informational guide pages and many thousands of photographs of [[arthropod]]s from the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] which are used for identification and research.<ref>{{cite journal|author=McCullough|first=Corinne|author2=Worthington|first2=Cakey|author3=Paradise|first3=Christopher J.|date=|title=Using Digital Macrophotography to Measure Biodiversity, Identify Insects, and Enhance Outreach and Education|url=https://academic.oup.com/ae/article/59/3/176/6825|journal=American Entomologist|publication-date=Fall 2013|volume=59|issue=3|pages=176–182|doi=10.1093/ae/59.3.176|via=}}</ref> The non-commercial site is hosted by the [[Iowa State University]] Department of Entomology. BugGuide was conceived by photographer Troy Bartlett in 2003 and since 2006 has been maintained by Dr. John VanDyk, Adjunct Assistant Professor of Entomology and Senior Systems Analyst at Iowa State University.<ref name="vanDyk1">[https://bugguide.net/user/view/612 "John VanDyk's Contributor Page"] on BugGuide.Net.</ref> The website has been recognized for helping change public perception of insects.<ref name="WebWatch">{{cite journal|last=Ahern|first=Kevin|date=|title=WebWatch – Done Buggy|url=https://www.future-science.com/doi/pdf/10.2144/000113266|journal=[[BioTechniques]]|publication-date=November 2009|volume=47|issue=5|page=909|pages=|doi=10.2144/000113266|via=}}</ref>
According to VanDyk, BugGuide had over 809 million hits in 2010, averaging approximately 26 hits per second.<ref name="VD_IOWA">{{cite web|url=https://archive.inside.iastate.edu/pdf/11/020311.pdf|title=Five questions for John VanDyk|last=Pounds|first=Diana|date=3 February 2011|website=|publisher=Inside Iowa State|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> He also stated that in early 2011 the site consisted of almost 34,000 written pages representing about 23 percent of the estimated insect species in North America.<ref name=VD_IOWA/> In April 2012 the guide surpassed 500,000 photos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ent.iastate.edu/bugguide_half_million|title=BugGuide passes the half million mark|last=|first=|date=May 2012|website=|publisher=[[Iowa State University]], Department of Entomology|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501194706/http://www.ent.iastate.edu/bugguide_half_million|archivedate=1 May 2012|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2 May 2012|df=}}</ref> By October 2014, BugGuide had 30,774 species pages and 48,572 total pages, with over 808,718 images submitted by more than 27,846 contributors.<ref name="BG_Stats">{{cite web|url=https://bugguide.net/node/view/11181|title=System Statistics|last=|first=|date=6 October 2014|website=BugGuide|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> On 22 September 2014, BugGuide surpassed 1,000,000 pages (most of which are photographs).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bugguide.net/node/view/1000000|title=longhorned beetle - ''Stenocorus vittiger''|last=|first=|date=|work=BugGuide|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref>
The photographs posted have contributed to or resulted in several scientific publications. A large proportion of images featured in an atlas of [[Vespidae|vespid wasps]]<ref name="Buck et al 2008">{{cite journal|last=Buck|first=Matthias|author2=Marshall|first2=Stephen A.|author3=Cheung|first3=David K.B.|date=|title=Identification Atlas of the Vespidae (Hymenoptera, Aculeata) of the northeastern Nearctic region|url=http://www.biology.ualberta.ca/bsc/ejournal/bmc_05/bmc_05.html|journal=Canadian Journal of Arthropod Identification|publication-date=19 February 2008|volume=5|pages=|doi=10.3752/cjai.2008.05|issn=1911-2173|accessdate=13 November 2013|via=}}</ref> are credited to contributors to BugGuide.<ref name="Marshall 2008">{{cite journal|last=Marshall|first=Stephen A.|date=|title=Field photography and the Democratization of Arthropod Taxonomy|url=https://academic.oup.com/ae/article/54/4/207/2474920|journal=American Entomologist|publication-date=Winter 2008|volume=54|issue=4|pages=207–210|doi=10.1093/ae/54.4.207|via=}}</ref> BugGuide photographs have detected new state records of invasive pest ants and beetles.<ref name="MacGown & Hill 2010">{{cite journal|last=MacGown|first=J.A.|author2=Hill|first2=J.G.|date=|year=2010|title=Two new exotic pest ants, ''Pseudomyrmex gracilis'' and ''Monomorium floricola'' (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) collected in Mississippi|url=http://midsouthentomologist.org.msstate.edu/pdfs/Vol3_2/Vol3_2_007.pdf|journal=Midsouth Entomologist|volume=3|pages=106–109|issn=1936-6019|via=}}</ref><ref name="Aalbu et al 2009">{{cite journal|last=Aalbu|first=Rolf L.|author2=Kanda|first2=Kojun|author3=Steiner|first3=Warren E., Jr.|date=|title=''Opatroides punctulatus'' Brullé now established in California (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae).|journal=The Pan-Pacific Entomologist|publication-date=April 2009|volume=85|issue=2|pages=38–42|doi=10.3956/2008-24.1|via=}}</ref>
Geologist and moth collector Richard Wilson said of the site, "The BugGuide site is very useful for anyone finding an insect and it is very interactive on getting it identified if a picture can be taken."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.opb.org/article/the_moth_man_of_bay_center/|title=The Moth Man of Bay Center|last=Gable|first=Cate|date=19 July 2011|website=|publisher=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref>
According to gardening author Margaret Roach, "The site is where naturalists of all levels share photos of 'insects, spiders and their kin' to foster enthusiasm and expand the knowledge base about these often-overlooked (and as BugGuide points out, 'oft-maligned') creatures."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://awaytogarden.com/why-im-abuzz-about-bugguide-net|title=why i'm abuzz about bugguide.net|author=Roach|first=Margaret|date=20 September 2012|work=A Way to Garden|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=13 December 2012}}</ref>
According to the site itself, BugGuide.net has been responsible for the identification of 11 new, previously undescribed species as of mid-2014. In addition, 12 species new to the Western Hemisphere were first identified via the site; another seven new to North America; and numerous new country records (primarily the United States) and state/county sightings.<ref name="newrecords">{{Cite web|url=https://bugguide.net/node/view/504744|title=Bug Guide firsts list for Latin American Bug Guide project|last=|first=|date=|website=BugGuide|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=6 August 2014}}</ref>

'''Cosmopolitan democracy''' is a political theory which explores the application of norms and values of [[democracy]] at the transnational and global sphere. It argues that [[global governance]] of the people, by the people, for the people is possible and needed. Writers advocating cosmopolitan democracy include [[Immanuel Kant]],<ref>Immanuel Kant, [http://www.constitution.org/kant/perpeace.htm ''Immanuel Kant, To perpetual peace: a philosophical sketch''], Hackett Publishing, 2003.</ref> [[David Held]],<ref>Daniele Archibugi & David Held, eds., [http://www.polity.co.uk/book.asp?ref=9780745613819 ''Cosmopolitan Democracy. An Agenda for a New World Order''], Polity Press, Cambridge, 1995.</ref><ref>[http://www.polity.co.uk/book.asp?ref=9780745600567 David Held, ''Democracy and the Global Order''], Polity Press, Cambridge, 1995</ref> [[Daniele Archibugi]],<ref>[[Daniele Archibugi]], [http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8737.html ''The Global Commonwealth of Citizens. Toward Cosmopolitan Democracy''], [[Princeton University Press]], Princeton, 2008</ref> [[Richard Falk]],<ref>Richard Falk, ''On Humane Governance'', Polity Press, Cambridge, 1998</ref> and [[Mary Kaldor]].<ref>Mary Kaldor, ''New and Old Wars'', Polity Press, Cambridge, 1999</ref> In the cosmopolitan democracy model, decisions are made by those affected, avoiding a single hierarchical form of authority. According to the nature of the issues at stake, democratic practice should be reinvented to take into account the will of stakeholders. This can be done either through direct participation or through elected representatives.<ref>Daniele Archibugi, [http://www.danielearchibugi.org/downloads/papers/Principles Principles of Cosmopolitan Democracy].</ref> The model advocated by cosmopolitan democrats is confederal and decentralized—[[global governance]] without [[world government]]—unlike those models of global governance supported by classic [[World Federalism]] thinkers, such as [[Albert Einstein]].
==Origin and development==
The victory of [[liberal democracies#Liberal democracies around the world|Western liberal states]] ending the [[Cold War]] inspired the hope that [[international relations]] could be guided by the ideals of [[democracy]] and the [[rule of law]]. In the early 1990s, a group of thinkers developed the political project of cosmopolitan democracy with the aim of providing intellectual arguments in favour of an expansion of democracy, both within states and at the global level. While some significant successes have been achieved in terms of democratization within states, much less has been attained in democratizing the global system.
In different forms, the necessity to expand democratic procedures beyond the nation-state has been supported by political philosopher [[Jürgen Habermas]],<ref>Jürgen Habermas, ''The Post-National Constellation'', MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 2001</ref> and sociologist [[Ulrich Beck]].<ref>Ulrich Beck, ''World Risk Society'', Polity Press, Cambridge, 1999</ref>
Criticisms of cosmopolitan democracy have come from [[political realism|realist]], [[marxist]], [[communitarian]] and [[multicultural]] perspectives. Democratic theorist [[Robert Dahl]]<ref>Robert Dahl, Can International Organizations be Democratic?, in Ian Shapiro and Casiano Hacker-Cordón (eds) (1999) ''Democracy’s Edges''. New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref> has expressed his doubts about the possibility of expanding democracy in international organizations to any significant degree, as he believes that democracy diminishes with size. Opponents of Dahl's approach point to the fact that bigger countries are not necessarily less democratic. For example, there is no correlation between voters' turnout and population size; in fact it is smallest in countries with fewer than 100,000 citizens. {{Citation needed|date=November 2015}}
==Political programme== The idea of cosmopolitan democracy has been advocated with reference to the reform of international organizations. This includes the institution of the [[International Criminal Court]], a directly elected [[World Parliament]] or world assembly of governments, and more widely the democratization of [[international organizations]].<ref>For an attempt to identify the political forces acting in favour of cosmopolitan democracy and the issues to be addressed, see [[Daniele Archibugi]] and [[David Held]], [http://www.danielearchibugi.org/downloads/papers/Archibugi_Held_CD%20Paths%20and%20Ways.pdf Cosmopolitan Democracy: Paths and Agents] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203000857/http://www.danielearchibugi.org/downloads/papers/Archibugi_Held_CD%20Paths%20and%20Ways.pdf |date=2013-12-03 }}, ''Ethics & International Affairs'', 25, no. 4 (2011), pp. 433-461.</ref> Supporters of cosmopolitan democracy have been sceptical about the effectiveness of military interventions, even when they are apparently motivated by [[Humanitarian intervention|humanitarian intentions]]. They have instead suggested popular [[diplomacy]] and [[arms control]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} '''Cultural cringe''', in [[cultural studies]] and [[social anthropology]], is an internalized [[inferiority complex]] that causes people in a country to dismiss their own culture as inferior to the cultures of other countries. It is closely related to the concept of [[colonial mentality]] and is often linked with the display of [[Anti-Intellectualism|anti-intellectual attitudes]] towards thinkers, scientists, and artists who originate from a colonial or [[post-colonial]] nation. It can also be manifested in individuals in the form of cultural alienation.
== Origin == In 1894, Australian [[bush poetry|bush poet]] [[Henry Lawson]] wrote in his preface to his ''Short Stories in Prose and Verse'': {{quote|The Australian writer, until he gets a "[[London]] hearing," is only accepted as an imitator of some recognized English or American author; and, as soon as he shows signs of coming to the front, he is labelled "The Australian [[Robert Southey|Southey]]," "The Australian [[Robert Burns|Burns]]," or "The Australian [[Bret Harte]]," and lately, "The Australian [[Rudyard Kipling|Kipling]]." Thus no matter how original he may be, he is branded, at the very start, as a plagiarist, and by his own country, which thinks, no doubt, that it is paying him a compliment and encouraging him, while it is really doing him a cruel and an almost irreparable injury. But mark! As soon as the Southern writer goes "home" and gets some recognition in England, he is "So-and-So, the well-known Australian author whose work has attracted so much attention in London lately"; and we first hear of him by cable, even though he might have been writing at his best for ten years in Australia.<ref>Colin Rodrick (ed.) Henry Lawson, Autobiographical and Other Writings 1887–1922 ([[Angus & Robertson]], 1972) pp.108–109</ref>}}
The term "cultural cringe" was coined in [[Australia]] after the Second World War by the [[Melbourne]] critic and social commentator [[A. A. Phillips]], and defined in an influential and highly controversial 1950 essay of the same name.<ref>{{cite book | last = Phillips | first = Arthur Angel | authorlink = A. A. Phillips | title = On the Cultural Cringe | publisher = [[Melbourne University Publishing]] | url = https://www.mup.com.au/items/9780522852219 |date=December 2005 | isbn = 0-522-85221-1 }}</ref> It explored ingrained feelings of inferiority that local intellectuals struggled against, and which were most clearly pronounced in the Australian theatre, music, art and letters. The implications of these insights potentially applied to all former colonial nations, and the essay is now recognised as a cornerstone in the development of [[Post-colonialism|post-colonial theory]] in Australia. In essence, Phillips pointed out that the public widely assumed that anything produced by local dramatists, actors, musicians, artists and writers was necessarily deficient when compared against the works of their British and European counterparts. In the words of the poet [[Chris Wallace-Crabbe]] (quoted by [[Peter Conrad (academic)|Peter Conrad]]<ref>{{cite news | title = Expatriate Games | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Expatriate-games/2005/03/24/1111525276948.html | publisher = ''[[The Age]]'' | date = 2005-03-25 | accessdate = 2007-01-17 }}</ref>), Australia was being made to rhyme with failure. The only ways local arts professionals could build themselves up in public esteem was either to follow overseas fashions, or, more often, to spend a period of time working in Britain.<ref name="When London Calls">{{cite book | last = Alomes | first = Stephen | authorlink = | title = When London Calls: The Expatriation of Australian Creative Artists to Britain | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1999 | location = Melbourne | url = | isbn = 0-521-62031-7 }}</ref><ref name="Once an Australian">{{cite book | last = Britain | first = Ian | authorlink = | title = Once an Australian: Journeys with Barry Humphries, Clive James, Germaine Greer and Robert Hughes | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1997 | location = Melbourne | url = | isbn = 0-19-553742-4 }}</ref>
As Lawson continued in his 1894 preface: "The same paltry spirit tried to dispose of the greatest of modern short-story writers as 'The Californian Dickens', but America wasn't built that way – neither was Bret Harte!" The cultural cringe of Australians and the cultural swagger of Americans reflects deep contrasts between the American and the Australian experiences of extricating themselves from English apron-strings. Dealing specifically with Australia, Phillips pointed out that ''sport'' has been the only field in which ordinary people accepted that their nation was able to perform and excel internationally. Indeed, while they prided themselves on the qualities of locally produced athletes and sportsmen, whom they invariably considered first rate, Australians behaved as if in more intellectual pursuits the nation generated only second-rate talent. Some commentators believe that cultural cringe contribute to the perceived [[anti-intellectualism]] that has underpinned public life in Australia.<ref>{{cite news | title = Anti-Intellectualism in Australia | url = http://www.abc.net.au/rn/talks/austback/stories/s198653.htm | publisher = [[Radio National]] | date = 2000-10-05 | accessdate = 2007-01-17 }}</ref>
==Connection with cultural alienation== The cultural cringe is tightly connected with "cultural alienation", that is, the process of devaluing or abandoning one's own culture or cultural background. A person who is culturally alienated places little value on their own or host culture, and instead hungers for that of a – sometimes imposed – colonising nation.<ref name="Empire Writes Back">{{cite book | last = Ashcroft | first = Bill | authorlink = | author2 = Gareth Griffiths | author3 = Helen Tiffin | title = The Empire Writes Back: Theory & Practice in Post-Colonial Studies | publisher = Routledge | year = 1989 | location = London | url = | isbn = 0-415-01209-0 | pages = 9–10, 61, 104–5, 144 }}</ref><ref name="Location of Culture">{{cite book | last = Bhabha | first = Homi | authorlink = | title = The Location of Culture | publisher = Routledge | year = 1994 | location = London | url = | isbn = 0-415-33639-2 | pages = }}</ref> The post-colonial theorists Bill Ashcroft, Gareth Griffiths and [[Helen Tiffin]] link alienation with a sense of dislocation or displacement some peoples (especially those from immigrant cultures) will feel when they look to a distant nation for their values.<ref name="Empire Writes Back"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.postcolonialweb.org/poldiscourse/ashcroft3f.html | title = Place and displacement | accessdate = 2007-01-18 | authorlink = | last = Ashcroft | first = Bill | year = 1989 | work = The Empire Writes Back: Theory and Practice in Post-Colonial Literatures | publisher = [[Routledge]] }}</ref> Culturally alienated societies often exhibit a weak sense of cultural self-identity and place little worth on themselves. It has been argued that the most common manifestation of this alienation among peoples from post-colonial nations at present is an appetite for all things American, from television and music, to clothing, slang, even names. However, the popularity of American culture across both formerly colonized and colonizer countries possibly negate this argument. Culturally alienated individuals will also exhibit little knowledge or interest in the history of their host society, placing no real value on such matters.<ref name="Empire Writes Back" />
The issue of cultural alienation has led the Australian sociologists [[Brian Head (sociologist)|Brian Head]] and [[James Walter (sociologist)|James Walter]] to interpret the cultural cringe as the belief that one's own country occupies a "subordinate cultural place on the periphery" and that "intellectual standards are set and innovations occur elsewhere."<ref name="another_look">{{cite book | last = Hume | first = Leonard John | authorlink = | title = Another Look at the Cultural Cringe | publisher = The Centre for Independent Studies | year = 1993 | location = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] | url = http://www.the-rathouse.com/Another_look_at_the_Cultural_Cringe.htm | isbn = 0-949769-89-4 }}</ref> As a consequence, a person who holds this belief is inclined to devalue their own country's cultural, academic and artistic life, and to venerate the "superior" culture of another (colonising) country.
A more sophisticated approach to the issues raised by the cultural cringe, as felt by artistic practitioners in former colonies around the world, was developed and advanced by the Australian art historian [[Terry Smith (art historian)|Terry Smith]] in his essay 'The Provincialism Problem'.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Smith | first = Terry | authorlink = Terry Smith (art historian) | date=September 1974 | title = The Provincialism Problem | journal =[[Artforum]] | pages = 54–59 }}</ref>
==By country==
===Australia=== [[File:Tom Wills carte de visite.jpg|thumb|It has been posited that Australia's "distinct ambivalence" towards its own history, coupled with a desire to rid the country of its "convict stain", resulted in historical figures such as star cricketer and Australian rules football founder [[Tom Wills]] being virtually forgotten.<ref>[[Gideon Haigh|Haigh, Gideon]] (2009). "Foreword". In Russell H. T., Stephens. ''Wills Way''. Playright Publishing. p. i. {{ISBN|9780977522682}}.</ref>]] The term cultural cringe is most commonly used in Australia, where it is believed by some to be a fact of Australian cultural life.<ref>Kenneth Minogue. "[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_n25_v47/ai_17774503 Cultural Cringe: Cultural Inferiority Complex and Republicanism in Australia]". ''[[National Review]]''. 31 December 1995. Retrieved 5 September 2006.</ref> In ''Another Look at the Cultural Cringe'',<ref name="another_look"/> the Australian academic Leonard John Hume examined the idea of cultural cringe as an oversimplification of the complexities of Australian history and culture. His controversial essay argues that "The cultural cringe ... did not exist, but it was needed, and so it was invented."
The cultural cringe can be expressed in the almost obsessive curiosity of Australians to know what foreigners think of Australia and its culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/07/10/1974488.htm |title=Getting over Australia's Cultural Cringe |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2007-07-10 |accessdate=2009-11-16}}</ref>
Some commentators claim the cultural cringe particularly affects local television programming in Australia,<ref>Tony Moore. "[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/08/18/1092765013665.html Cultural Cringe Keeps our History out of the Picture]". ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]''. 19 August 2004. Retrieved 1 January 2011.</ref> which is heavily influenced by imported shows, mainly of American and British origin. The Federal government has legislated to keep a quota of Australian content (Australian Content Standard and Television Program Standard 23).
Some argue that a form of cultural cringe resulted in anti-heritage attitudes which led to the demolition of many world class pre-war buildings in [[Melbourne]], [[Brisbane]] and [[Sydney]], destroying some of the world's best examples of [[Victorian architecture]].<ref>Simon Webster. "[http://www.theage.com.au/news/new-south-wales/construction-sights/2006/07/07/1152240479493.html Construction Sights]". ''[[The Age]]''. 9 July 2006. Retrieved 1 January 2011.</ref> Modernism was promoted to many Australians as casting off imperial Europe to rebuild a new independent identity, and the existing pre-war architecture, which was a feature of Australian cities, was denigrated.<ref>Blow S – The Marketing of modernism in Melbourne, 1950–1970</ref> This resulted in many calls to demolish the [[Royal Exhibition Building]], labelled the derogatory term "[[white elephant]]". It was not until [[Queen Elizabeth II]] granted the building Royal status that Australians began to recognise its value. The building became the first in Australia to be given [[World Heritage]] status.<ref>Guy Rundle. "[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/03/14/1079199092582.html?from=storyrhs Who will save Melbourne from the wrecker's ball?]". ''[[the Age]]''. 15 March 2004. Retrieved 1 January 2011.</ref> This reaction against the cultural cringe continues in some fields such as architecture, where local architects are shunned for using introduced styles.<ref>Gabriella Coslovich. "[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/kicking-against-the-bricks/2006/01/28/1138319484198.html Kicking against the bricks]". Interview with Leon van Schaik. ''[[The Age]]''. 29 January 2006. Retrieved 1 January 2011.</ref>
It has also been claimed that cultural cringe has led to federal government [[information technology]] contracts going to large foreign multinationals, rather than domestic IT companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crn.com.au/story.aspx?CIID=57787 |title=An unlevel playing field |author=Lilia Guan |publisher=Crn.com.au |date=2006-08-04 |accessdate=2009-11-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003152633/http://www.crn.com.au/story.aspx?CIID=57787 |archivedate=3 October 2006 |df= }}</ref>
Another manifestation of cultural cringe is the "[[convict stain]]". For several generations following the cessation of [[penal transportation]], many Australians felt a sense of shame about being descended from convicts, and many did not even attempt to investigate their families' origins for fear of finding convicts in their lineage. In recent decades community attitudes have changed, and many Australians with convict ancestors are now more comfortable investigating and discussing their past, wearing their forebears status almost as a badge of pride. Colloquially, attempts by non-Australians to negatively connote convict pasts are laughed off by Australians, who are now more inclined to associate criminal forebears as evidence for the possession of more positively perceived Australian attributes such as [[anti-authoritarianism]].<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/rn/latenightlive/stories/2008/2209906.htm The convict stain] Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Late Night Live. 8 April 2008</ref>
=== Brazil === In [[Brazil]], the phrase ''complexo de vira-lata'' (the "[[Mongrel complex]]") denotes the same as cultural cringe. It was allegedly coined by playwright and journalist, [[Nelson Rodrigues]], in the 1950s. The term is often evoked to criticize some attitude by any Brazilian toward a foreign culture or politics deemed as submissive and self-dismissive.
=== Canada === Many cultural commentators in Canada<ref>"[http://www.theknoll.ca/php/display.php?article_id=69&PHPSESSID=97ac8552e6e52cf977456d08cabf357f An 'Un-American' Cinema] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070319171932/http://www.theknoll.ca/php/display.php?article_id=69&PHPSESSID=1f4b9ceb8a82a0181ba56d7f7f97e467 |date=19 March 2007 }}", The Knoll. Retrieved 5 September 2006.</ref> have suggested that a similar process also operates in that country. The specific phrase "cultural cringe" is not widely used to label the phenomenon in Canada, although it has been used in isolated instances; more typically, Canadian cultural commentators speak of a "Canadian inferiority complex"<ref>Merrill Dennison. [http://www.empireclubfoundation.com/details.asp?SpeechID=2782 That Inferiority Complex] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113072738/http://www.empireclubfoundation.com/details.asp?SpeechID=2782 |date=13 November 2006 }} (address to The Empire Club).</ref> or label specific instances of the phenomenon with satirical terms such as "[[beaver hour]]".
Prior to the 1970s, Canadian radio stations gave almost no airtime to Canadian music, and apart from [[CBC Television]], Canadian television stations spent very little money on Canadian-produced programming; in response the [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC) developed [[Canadian content]] requirements for radio and broadcasters. Whether these 'Cancon' rules are necessary remains controversial.
===New Zealand=== New Zealanders are said to suffer from a cultural cringe, which has been wearing off in recent years.<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Annual Report 1999/2000 |work= |publisher=NZ On Air |year=2000 |url=http://www.nzonair.govt.nz/files/about/NZOA_ar_2000.pdf |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927064135/http://www.nzonair.govt.nz/files/about/NZOA_ar_2000.pdf |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> The [[New Zealand English]] accent is said to have been influenced by a cultural cringe since the 1900s but it too is lessening in recent years.<ref>{{cite book | last =Bayard | first =Donn | authorlink = | title = Kiwitalk: Sociolinguistics and New Zealand Society | publisher =Dunmore Press Ltd | year =1995 | location = | pages = | url = | isbn =0-86469-220-X }}</ref> It appears that the attitude has lessened markedly in the 2000s following the success of the award-winning ''[[Lord of the Rings]]'' movie trilogy which showcased much New Zealand scenery and film-making talent and boosted international awareness of New Zealand. The TV show ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]'', which screened on [[HBO]] in the United States from 2007–2009, furthered American and international awareness of New Zealand, as have motion pictures such as ''[[The World's Fastest Indian]]''.
=== Scotland === Scottish First Minister [[Jack McConnell]] claimed a "[[Scottish cringe]]" in relation to [[Scotland]]'s disdain for free enterprise.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/3494686.stm "I want to end the Scottish cringe"], BBC News, 28 February 2004. Retrieved 10 June 2006.</ref>
== See also == * [[Allophilia]] * [[Australian culture]] * [[Cargo cult]] (incl. [[Cargo cult#Metaphorical uses of the term|metaphorical uses of the term]]) * [[Law of Jante]] * [[Plastic Brit]] * [[Plastic Paddy]] * [[Post-colonialism]] * [[Self-hatred]] (e.g. [[Self-hating Jew]]) * [[Tall poppy syndrome]] * [[Wigger]] * [[Xenocentrism]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * A.A. Phillips, ''The Australian Tradition : Studies in Colonial Culture'', Melbourne, Cheshire, 1958

{{notability|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = Darlene Lim | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1972 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | home_town = | other_names = | pronounce = | residence = | citizenship = Canadian | nationality = | fields = Geobiology | workplaces = | patrons = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Toronto]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = Marianne Douglas | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = NASA research | influences = | influenced = | awards = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = | partner = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }}'''Darlene Sze Shien Lim''' is a [[NASA]] [[Geobiology|geobiologist]] and [[Astrobiology|exobiologist]] preparing astronauts for [[space colonization]]. She is considered a leading expert in Mars [[Human analog missions|analog missions]], having presented them publicly for [[NPR]], [[Learned society|academic societies]], and [[Mass media|print media]].
== Background == Lim is a first-generation Canadian; her parents emigrated from Singapore when she was a child.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/seti-institute/life-at-the-seti-institut_b_809258.html|title=Life at the SETI Institute: Darlene Lim -- Exploring the Watery Depths of Limnology|last=Institute|first=SETI|date=2011-01-19|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-03}} She grew up "...spending time in the [[Canadian Rockies]], and watching [Jacques Cousteau] on TV."{{Cite web|url=https://nautiluslive.org/people/darlene-lim|title=Darlene Lim|website=Nautilus Live|language=en|access-date=2018-12-03}} She studied biology while an undergraduate at [[Queen's University]], and credits Professor [[John Smol]] with igniting her interest in limnology, the study of lakes and ponds. Lim completed a doctoral degree in geology from the [[University of Toronto]], studying [[limnology]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/274753432_A_cyclonic_gyre_in_an_ice-covered_lake|title=A cyclonic gyre in an ice-covered lake {{!}} Request PDF|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2018-12-03}} She was already working on NASA-sponsored projects - such as the Haughton Mars Project, which involved studying arctic craters as Mars simulated environments{{Cite web|url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/leading-edge/nasa-mars-project-darlene-lim/|title=Life on Mars? - University of Toronto Magazine|website=University of Toronto Magazine|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-03}} - during her graduate studies. She became a postdoctoral researcher with Dr. Chris McKay at NASA's [[Ames Research Center|Ames Research]] Center in 2004, and later became a staff scientist and project leader.
== Public outreach == '''In popular media''' As part of her activities with [[SHAD (summer program)|SHAD]], Lim gave "...a dozen radio interviews" with [[CBC News|CBC]] throughout her undergraduate and Ph.D.{{Cite web|url=https://www.shad.ca/Media-Top16of2016.htm|title=Media-Top16of2016 - SHAD - Empowering Change Makers|website=www.shad.ca|access-date=2018-12-03}} Given her career was inspired in part by [[Jacques Cousteau]], a fitting panel appearance with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]] occurred in 2003 at Idea City.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/ideas-whose-time-are-here/article1017244/|title=Ideas whose time are here|access-date=2018-12-03}} From 2008-2009, Lim's work was part of IGLO, a traveling exhibit about exploring other planets.{{Cite journal|last=VanDorn|first=Bonnie|date=Jan/Feb 2008|title=ASTC Dimensions|url=http://www.astc.org/DimensionsPDFS/2008/JanFeb.pdf|journal=ASTC Dimensions|volume=|pages=21-22|via=}} She was the lead guest on the NASA Ames podcast in 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/ames/nisv-podcast-Darlene-Lim|title=Darlene Lim Talks About The Challenges Of Doing Science On Mar|last=Colen|first=Jerry|date=2016-11-16|work=NASA|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}} A profile of her Mars-simulation colony in Hawai'i (BASALT) appeared in the [[Chicago Tribune]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-nasa-mission-to-mars-20161210-story.html|title=How NASA is rehearsing for a mission to Mars|last=Kaplan|first=Sarah|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}} Lim appeared on the SAGANet "''Ask an Astrobiologist!''" streaming program in 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.spacetv.net/live/ask-an-astrobiologist-with-dr-darlene-lim/|title=Ask an Astrobiologist with Dr. Darlene Lim|work=SPACETV.NET|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}} She appeared twice on the ''[[Science Friday]]'' radio hour in 2018, contributing a 25-minute segment about undersea volcanic exploration tuned into by over 1 million listeners.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencefriday.com/segments/a-deep-ocean-dive-is-training-nasa-for-space/|title=A Deep Ocean Dive Is Training NASA For Space|work=Science Friday|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}} Lim participated in the Frontiers for Life in Space panel at the MIT Media Lab.{{Cite web|url=https://www.media.mit.edu/posts/beyond-the-cradle-2018-speakers/|title=Beyond the Cradle 2018 Speakers – MIT Media Lab|last=Ekblaw|first=Ariel|website=MIT Media Lab|access-date=2018-12-03}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.media.mit.edu/videos/darlene-lim-2017-10-03/|title=Scientific Analogs and the Development of Human Mission Architectures for Ocean and Space – MIT Media Lab|last=Bell|first=Katy Croff|website=MIT Media Lab|access-date=2018-12-03}} She was a judge in the HP "Home Mars" VR competition in 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.straight.com/life/1118191/what-city-one-million-people-mars-could-look|title=This is what a city of one million people could look like on Mars|date=2018-08-17|work=Georgia Straight Vancouver's News & Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.designworldonline.com/hp-mars-home-planet-premieres-virtual-reality-experience/|title=HP Mars Home Planet premieres virtual reality experience|date=2018-08-14|work=Design World|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}} '''Volunteer service''' Lim serves on the Ocean Exploration Advisory Board of [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.womeninspacecon.com/keynote-speakers|title=Keynote Speakers – Women in Space|website=www.womeninspacecon.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-03}} She served as a Scientist-in-Residence at the government of Canada's "Marsville" program from 2000 to 2002.{{Cite web|url=https://www.canada.ca/en/news/archive/2009/12/announcements-marsville-action-what-is-marsville-.html|title=Announcements - Marsville in Action: What is Marsville? - Canada.ca|last=Canada|first=Employment and Social Development|website=www.canada.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-12-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.imagiverse.org/interviews/darlenelim/05_03_04_darlene_lim.htm|title=Darlene Lim|website=www.imagiverse.org|access-date=2018-12-03}} From 2009-2015, she served as Co-Chair of the Mars Exploration Program Analysis Group Goal IV (Prepare for Human Exploration). Lim founded the Haven House Family Shelter [[STEM]] Explorer's Speaker series, to educate homeless children in San Francisco.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencefromscientists.org/news-and-events/register-now-for-stem-explorer-summer-program|title=Register Now for STEM Explorer Summer Program - Science from Scientists|date=2018-04-26|work=Science from Scientists|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}}
== Research and exploration == Lim has taken a decidedly nontraditional path, choosing government labs and public-facing space research over a traditional academic career. Lim has explored extreme environments worldwide, from Hawai'i{{Cite news|url=https://www.popsci.com/nasa-subsea-hawaii|title=NASA is preparing for future space missions by exploring underwater volcanoes off Hawaii|work=Popular Science|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}} and Florida to the [[Arctic]]{{Cite journal|last=Lim|first=Darlene S. S.|last2=Kwan|first2=Christine|last3=Douglas|first3=Marianne S. V.|date=2001-06-14|title=PERIPHYTIC DIATOM ASSEMBLAGES FROM BATHURST ISLAND, NUNAVUT, CANADIAN HIGH ARCTIC: AN EXAMINATION OF COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIPS AND HABITAT PREFERENCES|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1046/j.1529-8817.2001.037003379.x|journal=Journal of Phycology|language=en|volume=37|issue=3|pages=379–392|doi=10.1046/j.1529-8817.2001.037003379.x|issn=0022-3646}} and [[Antarctic]].{{Cite web|url=https://spacescience.arc.nasa.gov/finesse/people/darlene-lim/|title=Darlene Lim {{!}} FINESSE|website=spacescience.arc.nasa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-03}} Lim worked on data analysis for the ''Nautilus'' project, an initiative of [[Robert Ballard]]'s to explore and map the deep ocean. In 2000, Lim was an inaugural crew member in the first-ever Mars simulated colony in the Arctic (FMARS).{{Cite web|url=http://fmars.marssociety.org/|title=FMARS – Flashline Mars Arctic Research Station – Analogue research base owned by The Mars Society and located on Devon Island, Nunavut, Canada|website=fmars.marssociety.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-03}} She established the [[Pavilion Lake Research Project]] in 2004, studying microbial geologic formations underwater.{{Cite web|url=http://planets.ucla.edu/author/admin/page/9/|title=admin {{!}} UCLA Planets|website=planets.ucla.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-03}} In a 2017 interview, newly-minted astronaut [[Zena Cardman]] specifically calls out LIm as the reason she became interested in NASA exobiology projects.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/6/9/15768758/nasa-astronaut-class-2017-robb-kulin-zena-cardman-interview|title=A SpaceX engineer and marine biologist explain how they got picked to be NASA astronauts|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-12-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/06/nasa-s-new-astronaut-corps-features-abundance-scientific-talent|title=NASA’s new astronaut corps features an abundance of scientific talent|date=2017-06-28|work=Science {{!}} AAAS|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}} Lim is the Principal Investigator of SUBSEA, a biogeochemical analogue study for life on other planets.{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencefriday.com/person/darlene-lim/|title=Darlene Lim - Science Friday|work=Science Friday|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://spacescience.arc.nasa.gov/subsea/people/darlene-lim/|title=Darlene Lim – SUBSEA|website=spacescience.arc.nasa.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/news/tech/nasa-to-send-submarine-to-seafloor-near-hawaii-next-week-1844249.html|title=NASA to Send Submarine to Seafloor Near Hawaii Next Week|work=News18|access-date=2018-12-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/28/science/kilauea-volcanos-lava-fields-scientists-mars.html|title=Kilauea Volcano’s Lava Fields Offer Scientists a Portal to Mars|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}} This work hypothesizes future human exploration of [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] and [[Enceladus]], two [[Solar System]] moons with potentially habitable environments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/mach/science/how-underwater-volcano-could-help-scientists-find-extraterrestrial-life-ncna904736|title=How an underwater volcano could help scientists find extraterrestrial life|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}} Lim and colleague Jennifer Heldmann scouted extreme environments in Iceland in anticipation of a new mission kick-off in 2019.{{Cite news|url=https://grapevine.is/news/2018/05/24/nasa-starts-simulations-in-iceland-in-preparation-for-journey-to-mars/|title=NASA Starts Simulations In Iceland In Preparation For Journey To Mars|last=grapevine.is|date=2018-05-24|work=The Reykjavik Grapevine|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}}

{{Refimprove|article|date=August 2016}}
'''Dimensional metrology''' is the science of calibrating and using physical measurement equipment to quantify the physical size of or distance from any given object.
== History of metrology == Early Mesopotamian and Egyptian [[metrologist]]s created a set of measurement standards based on body measures such as fingers, palms, hands, feet, [[Cubit]]s, and paces and agricultural measures such as feet, yards, paces, fathoms, rods, cords, perch, stadia, miles and degrees of the Earth's circumference. Early Egyptian rulers based on units of fingers, palms and feet based on inscription grids that incorporated standards of measure as canons of proportion were made commensurate with Mesopotamian standards based on fingers, hands and feet so that four palms or three hands equaled one foot and ten hands equaled one meter. These standards which were used to measure and define property such as buildings and fields were adopted by the Greeks, Romans and Persians as legal standards and became the basis of European standards of measure. They were also used to relate length to area with units such as the khet, setat and aroura, area to volume with units such as the artaba and space to time with units such as the Egyptian minute of march, the itrw which recorded an hours travel on a river, and the days sail. Specialized units for carpenters, masons and other craftsmen such as the remen were worked into a system of unit fractions that allowed calculations utilizing analytic geometry. Carpenters and surveyors were some of the first dimensional inspectors.
== Tools == Modern measurement equipment include hand tools, CMMs ([[coordinate-measuring machine]]s), machine vision systems, laser trackers, and optical comparators. For hand tools, see [[Gauge (instrument)|gauge]]. A CMM is based on [[CNC]] technology to automate measurement of Cartesian coordinates using a touch probe, contact scanning probe, or non-contact sensor. Optical comparators are used when physically touching the part is undesirable. Instruments can now build 3D models of a part and its internal passages using x-ray technology or 3D laser scanners.
== Relative measurement == Measurements are often expressed as a size relative to a theoretically perfect part that has geometry defined in a print or computer model. A print is a blueprint illustrating the defined geometry of a part and its features. Each feature can have a size, a distance from other features, and a tolerance set on each element. The international language used to describe physical parts is called [[Geometric dimensioning and tolerancing|GD&T]]. Prints can be hand drawn or automatically generated by a computer [[CAD model]]. Computer controlled measurement systems can measure a part relative to a CAD model without the need for a print.
==Mechanical engineering== Industrial metrology is common in manufacturing quality control systems. The prints and CAD models described above are usually made by a [[mechanical engineer]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== * Annals of the CIRP Vol.26/2 (1977) https://www.nist.gov/sites/default/files/documents/calibrations/cirp26-2.pdf Three Dimensional Metrology Key-Note-Papers NIST

[[File:Emanoil Bacaloglu.jpg|thumb|right|Emanoil Bacaloglu]]
'''Emanoil Bacaloglu''' ({{IPA-ro|emanoˈil bakaˈloɡlu}}; 11 April 1830 – 30 August 1891) was a [[Wallachia]]n and [[Romania]]n [[mathematician]], [[physicist]] and [[chemist]] and a scubadiver, medic, shoe salesman, a vegetarian,policeman and fireman.
Born in [[Bucharest]] and of [[Greeks of Romania|Greek]] origin, he studied physics and mathematics in [[Paris]] and [[Leipzig]], later becoming a professor at the [[University of Bucharest]] and, in 1879, a [[list of members of the Romanian Academy|member of the Romanian Academy]]. Considered to be the founder of many scientific and technological fields in Romania (and aiding in the creation of the [[Romanian Athenaeum]]), Bacaloglu was also an accomplished scientist. He helped create Romanian-language terminology in his fields and was one of the principal founders of the Society of Physical Sciences in 1890.
He was also a participant in the [[1848 Wallachian revolution]].
He is known for the "Bacaloglu [[pseudosphere]]". This is a [[surface of revolution]] for which the "Bacaloglu [[curvature]]" is constant.
==Main works== * ''Elemente de fizică'', 2nd ed., Bucureşti, (1888). * ''Elemente de algebră'', 2nd ed., Bucureşti, (1870).
==References== * Florica Câmpan, "La pseudosphère de Bacaloglu", Acad. Roum. Bull. Sect. Sci. 24 (1943), 96–105. {{MathSciNet|id=0024191}}
